metadata.title: AuI as a cheap, nontoxic, and efficient alternate to commercial mercury catalyst for production of vinyl chloride monomer

Fig. 1 Morphology of AC1. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Morphology of AC2. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of 1Au(Cl3)/AC1 and 1Au(I)/AC1. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 XRD patterns of AC1, 1Au(Cl3)/AC1 and 1Au(I)/AC1 treated by HCl for 30 min. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Long-term testing of 0.1Au(I)/AC2 and commercial mercury-based catalyst 8.8Hg(Cl2)/ EAC. Reaction Conditions: C2H2 flow rate = 26.8 mL/min, HCl/C2H2 = 1.13, Temp = 180 °C, MHSV = 4.84 /h. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Conversion of acetylene over 0.1Au(Cl3)/AC1, 0.1Au(I)/AC1, 0.1Au(Cl3)/AC2 and 0.1Au(I)/AC2. Reaction Conditions: C2H2 flow rate = 26.8 mL/min, HCl/C2H2 = 1.13, Temp = 180 °C, MHSV = 4.84 /h. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Conversion of acetylene over 0.1Au(Cl3)/AC1, 0.1Au(I)/AC1, 0.1Au(Cl3)+KCl/AC1 and 1.25KI/AC1. Reaction Conditions: C2H2 flow rate = 26.8 mL/min, HCl/C2H2 = 1.13, Temp = 180 °C, MHSV = 4.84 /h. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 (a) Conversion of acetylene and (b) selectivity of VCM over C2H2 treated 0.1Au(Cl3)/AC2 and 0.1Au(I)/AC2. Before testing, both samples were treated by pure C2H2 for 3 h under 240 °C, with a flow rate of 26.8 mL/min. Reaction Conditions: C2H2 flow rate = 26.8 mL/min, HCl/C2H2 = 1.13, Temp = 180 °C, MHSV = 4.84 /h. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Optimized structures of C2H2, AuCl3, Cl3Au(η2-C2H2), AuI and IAu(η2-C2H2). Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Frontier molecular orbital (FMOs) of A) AuCl3, B) Cl3Au(η2-C2H2) was thus activated because of electrons imported into t, C) AuI and D) IAu(η2-C2H2). Color of atom: Au-golden, Cl-green, C-gray, H-light gray, I- purple (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Fig. 10 Table 1 Textural properties of AC1 and AC2. AuI as a cheap, nontoxic, and efficient alternate to commercial mercury catalyst for production of vinyl chloride monomer Yulun Chai a Xiaohui Tian a Binbo Jiang a ⁎ Jingdai Wang a Yongrong Yang a Mingzhen Zhang b a Zhejiang Provincial Key Laboratory of Advanced Chemical Engineering Manufacture Technology, State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, College of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, PR China Zhejiang Provincial Key Laboratory of Advanced Chemical Engineering Manufacture Technology State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering College of Chemical and Biological Engineering Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310027 PR China b Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, The University of Akron, Akron, OH, 44325, USA Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering The University of Akron Akron OH 44325 USA ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Production of vinyl chloride monomer (VCM) via acetylene hydrochlorination reaction (AHR) is consuming huge amount of mercury catalyst that is highly toxic. A cheap, nontoxic, and effective alternate is urgently required. Here, we designed an AuI catalyst for AHR with the excellent catalytic performance. The designed 0.1AuI(wt%)/AC2 catalyst shows the comparable catalytic efficiency to the commercial mercury catalyst, which is applicable for industrial production of VCM. Theoretical calculations determine the activation mechanism of C2H2 by AuI, and highlight the high stability of AuI. Keywords Acetylene Hydrochlorination AuI Gold catalyst Density functional theory 1 Introduction The route of acetylene hydrochlorination reaction (AHR) has contributed to 70% of PVC (polyvinyl chloride) production ability in China. The large consumption of mercury-based catalyst (HgCl2/C) results in the huge environmental toxicity, which is drawing extensive attentions. More than 60% mercury consumption was used in the VCM. Great efforts have been made to develop the non-toxic alternative. Nevertheless, mercury-free catalyst has been unavailable because: 1) the base metals have limited activities, 2) the noble metals are extremely expensive, and 3) the promising catalyst such as Au/C, suffers from deactivation. As one of “catalysis gold rush”, AHR (acetylene hydrochlorination reaction) shows the great potential as an ideal reaction system for gold catalyst design. Previous works have [1–3] identified the valence state of active sites and the deactivation mechanism, designed the reactivation techniques and proposed a mechanism of catalyzed reaction, providing the solid basis and greatly advancing the gold catalyst design towards VCM. Despite some examples of the commercialization [4,5], the gold catalysts are still too expensive for AHR. The gold catalyzed AHR is a typical coordination catalysis over heterogeneous catalysts, with a core step of forming the organometallic structure of LnAuδ +(η2-C2H2) (L denotes anion or neutral ligand; n is the number of ligands, an integer. η2 is hapticity) to facilitate acetylene activation. As homogeneous catalysis, transient structure of LnAuδ +(η2-C2H2) and the structure of activated C2H2 associated with the valence of Au and ligands are crucial for the catalytic performance. These factors may provide the basis for rational catalyst design. However, compared to the great achievements in homogeneous gold catalysis, the heterogeneously catalyzed AHR has been less reported [5–7]. Au+ has a noticeable standard electrode potential, which is higher than Au3+ (E°(Au+) = 1.68 > E°(Au3+) = 1.50). According to the Hutchings’ theory [5], it refers to the higher activity. The stability constants complexes are also used to determine the stability of Au+ and Au3+ compounds [6]. The excellent performance of 0.1Au/C (wt %) in AHR by using Na3Au(S2O3)2 as the Au precursor complex was observed. In 2017, Hutchings [7] proposed that the activity of cationic Au correlates with the ratio of Au(I): Au(III). However, LnAuδ +(η2-C2H2) has not been well studied. Catalyst design is challenging in absence of the comprehensive understanding of the organometallic structure, LnAuδ +(η2-C2H2). Herein, we employed two gold compounds, AuCl3 (d8) and AuI (d10), to explore their catalytic performance in VCM. First, the intrinsic chemistry of Cl3Au(3+)(η2-C2H2) and IAu(+)(η2-C2H2) during/after C2H2 activation was analyzed by theoretical calculations. The catalytic performance of AuCl3 and AuI was then experimentally compared. We for the first time explored 1) the activation mechanism of C2H2, 2) the ligand design during fabrication of heterogeneous AHR catalyst, and 3) a low-price/prominent AuI-based catalyst. The designed AuI catalyst shows a higher total TOF (4582 h−1) than Na3Au(S2O3)2 (3455 h−1) [6]. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and reagents HAuCl4·4H2O (assay 49%) and C2H5OH were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Company (Shanghai, China); Two kinds of activated carbons (referred to subsequently as AC1 and AC2, 20∼40 mesh) was obtained from Jiangsu Yonghua Fine Chemicals Co., Ltd. The surface property of the carbons was shown in Table 1 , Figs. 1 and 2 ); Highly purified Hydrogen Chloride (99.998%) was provided by Shanghai Weichuang Standard Gas Analytical Technology Co., Ltd.; Acetylene (99.5%) was purchased from Jiaxing Tianli Gas Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The activated carbon C was initially washed with dilute aqueous HCl (1 mol/L) at 70 °C for 5 h to remove residual alkali species. This mixture was filtered and washed with distilled water till pH = 7 and then dried at 140 °C for 12–18 hours. Before impregnation, activated carbon was exposed in air for 10 min to adsorb some water on its surface. Catalysts supported on activated carbon, AuCl3/AC and AuI/AC, were prepared in accordance with the PI (pore-volume impregnation) technique. The synthesis procedure of AuCl3/AC was as follows. Proper amount of HAuCl4 dissolved in aqua regia (according to pore volume of AC) was added dropwise to the activated carbon support under shaking. Addition of KI into the yellow HAuCl4 aqueous solution (without aqua regia) resulted in a brown solution. Then, the wet products (both AuCl3 and AuI) were kept at room temperature for 2 h, and then dried at 140 °C for 18 h. Aqua regia was adopted during preparation of AuCl3-based catalyst aiming to preserve the valence state of Au3+. However, compared to water, aqua regia improved the catalytic activity only slightly, since experimental results have demonstrated that without careful design of ligand, Au+ and Au3+ almost showed the same activity that was slightly higher than Au°. AuI, which is difficult to dissolve in pure water, inquires excess amount of I− in the solution to give transparent mixture (Au: I = 1: 14.8 (molar ratio)). This led to 12.5% (in mass) KI in the catalyst containing 1% Au, so that the redundant KI would be anchored at the carbon surface and affected the catalytic stability. Thus, catalysts containing only 0.1% Au (and 1.25% KI, in mass, the same hereinafter) were prepared. Ordinary gold catalyst, denoted as Au/AC1, was prepared according with the PI technique. Proper amount of HAuCl4 aqueous solution (according to pore volume of C1) was added dropwise to the activated carbon support under shaking. After that, the wet product was kept at room temperature for 2 h to gain a better impregnation. The sample was then dried at 140 °C for 18 h before being collected for use. Mass ratio of Au on different samples and its precursor was denoted as xAu(Cl3 or I). For example, 0.1Au(I)/AC1 indicated that the Au content was 0.1 wt. %, and it was a catalyst featuring AuI using AC1. 2.3 Catalyst testing AHR was carried out in a fixed bed laboratory microreactor. Catalysts were tested using a stainless-steel reactor tube (i.d. of 8 mm). 1.0 g of the synthesized catalyst was sandwiched between glass pearls inside the reactor for each run. N2 was used as purging gas and the reactor was operated at atmospheric pressure at 180 °C, in down-flow mode. After being heated to 180 °C, hydrogen chloride was regulated by mass flow controllers and fed into the reactor alone for 20 min to activate the catalyst according to industrial process. After that acetylene was introduced into concentrated sulfuric acid to remove trace poisonous impurities such as acetone, moisture, S, P and As, and subsequently fed into the reactor to start the reaction. Pressure of the reactants, namely HCl and C2H2, was chosen for safety and in accordance with industrial condition. A total MHSV (mass hourly space velocity) of 4.84 h−1 was used for catalyst testing. Conversion of acetylene was not too high in this situation. Thus, the results obtained were in kinetic regime. A reactor loaded with 1.0 g bare activated carbon presented only slight reactivity for AHR (< 0.3% conversion of acetylene at 1 h on-stream). The gas product passed through a vessel filled with 15% sodium hydroxide solution and a drying tube in sequence to remove the remaining hydrogen chloride and moisture. The composition of the effluent was determined immediately using a gas chromatography equipped with a flame ionization detector. The catalyst performances were evaluated by conversion of acetylene (XA), selectivity of VCM (S VCM ) and the deactivation rate (DR) as Eqs. (1)–(3) (1) X A = φ VCM ×100% (2) S V C M = φ V C M 1 - φ A × 100 % (3) D R = X A L - X A H t Where φ A and φ VCM were the volume fraction of remaining acetylene and VCM in gas product separately, X A H and X A L refered to the highest and the last X A obtained respectively during the experiment. Time span from X A H to X A L was denoted as t, in units of hours. Gold dispersion, the fraction of surface atoms that were supposed to be reactants in heterogeneous catalysts was difficult to be precisely calculated. Thus, turnover frequency (TOF) of gold-based catalyst was calculated according to its total consumption. This provided a more accurate description of the efficiency of the expensive catalyst. The TOF was computed as Eq. (4) (4) TOF= mol of acetylene converted mol of metal × time (h) 2.4 Catalyst characterization UV-vis: X-ray powder diffraction spectra (XRD) were acquired with a Philips PW3050/60 vertical goniometer using Ni-filtered Cu Kα1 radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). A proportional counter and a 0.02° step size in the 2θ range from 5 to 80°. The assignment of the various crystalline phases is based on the JPDS powder diffraction file cards. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy(XPS) were attempted but proved inconsequential. 2.5 Theoretical calculation protocol Structural optimizations of monomeric C2H2, AuCl3 and AuI molecules and the Cl3Au(η2-C2H2) and IAu(η2-C2H2) complexes were carried out by density functional theory (DFT). The basis set of cc-Pvtz for H, C and Cl atoms and cc-pVTZ-pp for Au and I, and the Becke’s three-parameter hybrid exchange function with Lee-Yang-Parr gradient-corrected correlation functional (B3LYP) were employed for the calculations in Gaussian 09 program suite. No constrains of symmetry, bonds, angles or dihedral angles were applied. The local minima of the optimized structures were confirmed by the absence of an imaginary mode in vibrational analysis. The optimized systems were subjected to the Natural population analysis (NPA) by the natural bond orbital (NBO) to evaluate orbitals and electrons. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of AuI in VCM Fig. 3 shows that the XRD patterns of 1% Au containing samples, either featuring AuCl3 or AuI, lack the sign of FCC gold (dotted line). This implies that no obvious reduction occurred in both situations. It is interesting that, due to the high E°, AuI is stable enough in the hot water and air during the drying process. For AuCl3, the absence of aqua regia caused Au3+ reduction during the drying process [8,9]. Fig. 4 shows the XRD patterns of AC1, 1% Au containing samples, either featuring AuCl3 or AuI treated by HCl for 30 min. The AuCl3 shows the sign of FCC gold (dotted line), indicating that the reduction occurred in 1AuCl3, similar to Monnier’s work [10]. However, this was not found for AuI, suggesting that the iodide stabilizes dispersed Au to protect Au+ from being reduced. We compared the catalytic performance of 0.1Au(I)/AC2 to the industrial catalyst. The industrial mercury-based catalyst, denoted as 8.8Hg (Cl2)/EAC (extruded activated carbon, 3 × 6 mm), contains about 8.8% of Hg. It was grounded and sieved to 20∼40 mesh before testing. The experiment was conducted in a fixed bed reactor (i.d. of 14 mm) following the reaction conditions introduced in section 2.4. A total MHSV of 4.84 h−1 was chosen whilst the conversion of acetylene was kept below 80% to avoid diffusion control of both samples (Table 2 ). Fig. 5 shows that the industrial catalyst showed very high initial catalytic activity and gradually deactivated. By contrast, although 0.1Au(I)/AC2 only exhibits the initial activity as half as industrial catalyst, it showed excellent stability in the long-time testing. The calculations show that the deactivation rate of 0.1Au(I)/AC2 was only one fifth of 8.8Hg(Cl2)/EAC. At the ending point of catalysis, 0.1Au(I)/AC2 leads to 71% of the industrial sample’s VCM production, suggesting that 0.1Au(I)/AC2 exhibit the comparable efficiency to mercury catalyst. Fig. 6 shows the catalytic performance of 0.1Au(Cl3)/AC2 and 0.1Au(I)/AC2. Due to the different carbon surfaces, 0.1Au(I)/AC2 was 25% more active than 0.1Au(I)/AC1. The calculated TOF of 0.1Au(I)/AC2 (5800 h−1) was twice higher than the highest TOF value of gold catalyst ever reported for acetylene hydrochlorination since 1985 [1–3]. Fig. 7 shows the catalytic performance of 0.1Au(Cl3)/AC1, 0.1Au(I)/AC1 and a control sample in acetylene hydrochlorination reaction. The 0.1Au(I)/AC1 showed a much higher catalytic activity than 0.1Au(Cl3)/AC1. The calculated TOF of 0.1Au(I)/AC1 (4582h-1) was 2.7 times higher than 0.1Au(Cl3)/AC1 (1697 h−1). The control sample, using equimolar amount of KCl to replace KI, showed only 28% activity enhancement. Catalyst containing only 1.25% KI showed undetectable catalytic activity. These results suggest that the superior activity of 0.1Au(I)/AC1 derived from formation of AuI, rather than the immediate consequence of K+ or KI. Moreover, two samples presented in Figs. 5 and 6 had the similar selectivity toward VCM, i.e., 99.94% for AuCl3 and 99.98% for AuI (not shown), but showed the different selectivity after calcination in C2H2. As shown in Fig. 8 , VCM selectivity of 0.1Au(Cl3)/AC2 dropped by 0.9% after C2H2 treatment. It is possible that one of the four coordinate sites of Au3+ was substituted by other ligand during calcination, changing its catalytic behavior. After the C2H2 treatment, the increase in metallic gold amount would destroy the structural sensitivity related catalysis routes of FCC gold in the reaction [5,6]. These structural isoforms, with the synergistic effects, may be responsible for the selectivity drop of 0.1Au(Cl3)/AC2. In sharp contrast, the selectivity of 0.1Au(I)/AC2 after the treatment stayed almost unchanged (99.7%). This may due to following reasons. For the first, the limited number of coordinate sites may hamper the probability of ligand substitution of Au+. Secondly, the high E° of Au+ may help resist reduction of it to metallic form, thus avoiding FCC related catalytic side reactions. These results suggest that AuI is a better alternative catalyst in acetylene hydrochlorination. 3.2 Mechanism of excellent catalytic performance of AuI in VCM Fig. 9 shows the optimized structures of C2H2, AuCl3 and AuI, with the important structural parameters summarized in Table 3 . The calculated bond lengths of C2H2 (CC and CH) were in good agreement with experimental data. Monomeric AuCl3 presented a T–shaped, rather than equilateral triangle, structure due to the Jahn–Teller effect 11]. In line with the reported values, the bond length of Au–Cl1 (2.274 Å) slightly was longer than Au–Cl3 (2.254 Å), with the Cl1–Au–Cl2 angle up to 166.2° [11,12]. The bond length of optimized AuI was 2.536 Å, which was slightly shorter than previous theoretical works [13,14]. This is likely due to the different theories selected. The experimental structure of AuI is unavailable. Thus, we further optimized the structures of AuF, AuCl and AuBr by the same theoretical methods, and compared the computational results with experiments. The calculated bond lengths were highly consistent with the available experimental data, confirming the reliability of the computational protocols selected in this work [15]. AuCl3 and AuI activate C2H2 by generating the electroneutral structures. Fig. 9 shows the optimized structures of Cl3Au(η2-C2H2) and IAu(η2-C2H2) complexes. The axis of CC triple bond was perpendicular to the AuCl3 surface in Cl3Au(η2-C2H2). This conformation was expected to be favored due to the overlapped orbitals. Similar phenomenon has been observed in previous works [16]. Upon binding to AuCl3, the HCC angle decreased from 180 to 171.9, CC distance increased from 1.201 to 1.215 Å, and the Wiberg bond index between C centers declined from 2.999 to 2.621. These structural changes indicate the activation of triple bond. The T-shaped AuCl3 was also affected by the C2H2, with the Cl1–Au–Cl2 angle and Au–Cl bond lengths increased. More significant distortion of C2H2 was observed in IAu(η2-C2H2) complex. In IAu(η2-C2H2), the HCC angle was 165.1°, and CC distance increased to 1.227 Å. Wiberg bond index of the two C centers decreased to 2.606. The distance between the Au center and CC bond was 2.108 Å, shorter than that in Cl3Au(η2C2H2) (2.241 Å) complex. The bond length of Au–I increased from 2.536 to 2.559 Å. Adsorption energy between molecular pairs, i.e., AuCl3/C2H2 and AuI/C2H2, was –86.4 and –118.9 kJ mol−1 respectively, suggesting that AuI had a stronger affinity toward C2H2. These results suggest a stronger activation capacity of AuI toward C2H2, compared to AuCl3. Analysis of bonding between Au and CC by Dewar–Chatt–Duncanson (DCD) model provide the important sights into CC activations. The π-back-donation weakened CC triple bond via inducing its structural changes and promoting the following reactions. According to DCD model, a synergistic metal→ligand σ bond (between Au 5 d x 2 - y 2 (or Au sp hybrid orbital) and π-orbital of CC) and metal→ligand π-back-donation (between Au 5 d y z and empty antibonding π* orbital of CC) was formed. Table 4 summarizes the electrons occupations in gold valence shells by the NBO population analysis. The electronic feedback capability of the 5dyz d track (the decrease of the number of electronic cloth settlements) followed the order of AuCl3 < AuI. In both AuCl3 and AuI (and their corresponding C2H2 coordinated structures), 5d orbitals of gold involved in the chemical bonding. This is due to relativistic effect of gold that stabilized the 6s shell (contraction) and destabilized the 5d shell (expansion), which consequently narrowed the energy gap between orbitals [16,17]. It should be noted that 6p orbitals of gold also participated in the bonding in AuCl3, supporting that d8 Au3+ adopts dsp2 hybridization and favors planar coordination structure. Thus, formation of σ bond could be determined by the electron density increase in Au 5 d x 2 - y 2 and 6s, 6p orbitals in Cl3Au(η2-C2H2). For IAu(η2-C2H2), the Au sp hybrid orbital participated in this process, with the electron increase in only 6s and 6p orbitals. Table 4 shows that the electron accumulation and the enhanced HCl affinity of C atoms (to produce VCM). It has been shown that the stability of Au+ complexes is better than Au3+ complexes. Minor electron depletion from 5 d y z (0.068, see Table 4) were observed while C2H2 binds to AuCl3. C2H2 in Cl3Au(η2-C2H2) was thus activated because of electrons imported into the π* orbital. Meantime, for IAu(η2-C2H2), more electrons (0.176) flew out from 5 d y z to C2H2, suggesting a stronger back donation effect of AuI and its superiority in C2H2 activation. This matches the structure transformations abating its flavor stability of adsorbed C2H2. Moreover, the NBO charge of Au decreased when AuCl3 interacts with C2H2, implying the net transferring of electrons from C2H2 to Au center. This net electron decrease on C atoms may prevent its interaction with HCl, given that HCl is a good electrophilic reagent. By contrast, there was a net increase of NBO charge on Au center in IAu(η2-C2H2). Frontier molecular orbital (FMO) theory was employed to study the electron density distributions of calculated molecules. The parameters of frontier orbitals and shape of them are showed in Fig. 10 , Table 5–7 . The apparent Au 5d orbital contribution to the HOMO and HOMO-1 were observed for both AuCl3 and AuI, in line with significance of an occupied d orbital to back-donate electrons. The higher level of π-back-donation in IAu(η2-C2H2) originated from the smaller energy gap between involved orbitals. The HOMO energy of AuI (-6.9963 eV) is closer to LUMO of C2H2 (-0.7265 eV), compared to AuCl3 (8.5490 eV), indicating its higher capacity of HOMO-LOMO electron transfer. Different from AuI, LUMO energy of AuCl3 (6.3397 eV) is closer to HOMO energy of C2H2 (8.1471 eV), which prefers stronger σ bond between those two molecules than the situation of IAu(η2-C2H2). Moreover, the higher charge of Au3+ intends to afford higher affinity toward the electrons in C2H2 and hamper π-back-donation to corresponding orbital. All these effects together lead to the net charge transformation on Au core and C atoms during formation of Cl3Au(η2-C2H2) and IAu(η2-C2H2). It was found that AuI had a Fermi level closer to that of C2H2, which might be the reason of the higher adsorption energy. The energy gap between HOMO-1 and HOMO, in both AuI and AuCl3, were minor. Hence, all these orbitals might participate in the bonding process. This is similar in C2H2, since its HOMO-1 and HOMO, or LUMO and LUMO + 1, are degenerate orbitals. The activation of C2H2 is followed by the interaction between the complex and HCl. The route it takes has a great impact on the entire reaction rate. We sketched this process via the FMO analysis. HCl may function as either a nucleophile or an electrophile by Cl or H motifs. HCl executes the nucleophilic attack to the LUMO and electrophilic attack to the HOMO of targets Due to the relativistic effect, most gold compounds in the oxidation state +3 are tetramer, planar and 16 electron species. This implies that association of additional Cl (in HCl, nucleophilic attack) to Au center is improbable, although the LUMO of Cl3Au(η2-C2H2) contains Au d contribution (29%, Fig. 5 and Table 5). Besides, the slight C p contribution in the LUMO (5% of each C) indicates the low possibility of direct Cl attack to activated C2H2. The HOMO of Cl3Au(η2-C2H2) comprises no Au 5d orbital contribution and other atomic orbitals of Au, implying the loss of electron donating ability of Au center. Thus, Au in Cl3Au(η2-C2H2) is expected to not interact with the electrophilic center in HCl (here refers to H). Other possibilities include the break of Au-Cl and formation of Au-Cl-H (substitution mechanism), or direct buildup of Au-Cl-H-Cl. Both may enable the activation of HCl and following reactions. Conte [9] has identified the formation of Au-Cl…H-Cl after C2H2 adsorption, in which the hydrogen bonding between H (from HCl) and Cl in the o-position of C2H2 play the key role (from the complex). Considering that HOMO of Cl3Au(η2-C2H2) mainly consisted of occupied Cl p orbitals (Fig. 10 and Table 6), this mechanism is theoretically reasonable. The absence of Au 5d orbital contribution to the HOMO of Cl3Au(η2-C2H2) is consistent with Pernpointner and Hashmi [15]. For IAu(η2-C2H2), the LUMO contains contributions from Au orbitals (Fig. 10 and Table 6), mediating its interaction with Cl (from HCl) via a three-coordinate structure. Moreover, in contrast to Cl3Au(η2-C2H2), the prevailing C p participation in LUMO (and LUMO + 1) implies that hydrochlorination of IAu(η2-C2H2) is likely to take place through an outer-sphere mechanism. Cl attacks C, instead of Au center, to initiate the further reactions, which may simplify the reaction process and accelerate the reaction rate. This proposition is in accordance with the conclusions reported in the previous literatures [15–18]. The absence of o-position halogen atom (I) in IAu(η2-C2H2) indicates that Au-I…H-Cl mechanism is not possible. However, atomic orbitals of Au participate in the HOMO of IAu(η2-C2H2), is different from Cl3Au(η2-C2H2) (Fig. 10 and Table 6). The presence of Au orbitals suggests that the Au core in IAu(η2-C2H2) exhibits the electron donating capacity, which may facilitate the three-coordinate structure of Au+. Because of a much longer distance between Au and H (than Au I), the three-coordinate structure of Au+ may be a result of metal-hydrogen bond that can activate HCl. However, Au+ intends to form two coordinate, planar and 14 electron structures because of the intensive relativistic effect. Therefore, the application of three coordinate mechanism needs the further verification. Composition of LUMO + 1 (Fig. 10 and Table 7) further supports the higher possibility of outer-sphere mechanism. However, the energy gaps between LUMO and LUMO + 1 is large. Hence, the participation of LUMO + 1 in further reaction carries little possibility, even though they comprise atomic orbitals of Au or C. Catalysts featuring AuCl3 suffer from deactivation in applications. Activity loss of AuCl3-based catalyst is mainly due to the reduction of Au3+ to its less active elemental form. Based on the calculation results, it is reasonable to deduce that the weakened Au–Cl bonds in Cl3Au(η2-C2H2) might undergo reductive elimination pathways at the heteroatom-rich carbon surface, resulting in reduction of Au3+ to Au+ species. The obtained soft base Au+, in surrounding of the hard-base Cl–, is unstable in the reaction conditions. Thus, it tends to be reduced to metallic gold, and suffers from deactivation. However, AuCl3 was still undisputedly the most active and stable noble metal catalyst ever reported for acetylene hydrochlorination. The stability of AuCl3-based catalysts might be related to its high E0, which can help resist its reduction to certain extent. According to calculation results, the AuCl3 in Cl3Au(η2-C2H2) exhibits very different structure compared to the free molecule. Despite the remarkable augment of ∠Cl1–Au–Cl2, bond lengths of Au–Cl1 and Au–Cl3 are prolonged by 2.15% (0.049 Å) and 1.10% (0.025 Å) respectively. However, Au–I in IAu(η2-C2H2) is only 0.91% (0.023 Å) longer than that in free AuI. Table 3 further shows that great decrease of NBO charge (0.135 e, 28.5%) at the gold center of AuCl3 before and after C2H2 coordination. By contrast, just 0.022 e, 9.1% NBO charge increase at the gold center of AuI is observed. The former case would inevitably lead to valence drop of Au3+ and the latter preserves Au+. Furthermore, FMO energy gap (Table 6) implied the easier electron excitation from o-position Cl–, whose p orbitals constitutes the HOMO and has been activated (lengthen of Au–Cl1). These differing transformations, all pointing to the high stability of AuI in the reaction circumstance, are largely related to the outer valence orbitals. The Au+ has a noticeable standard electrode potential that is greater than Au3+ (E°(Au+) = 1.68 > E°(Au3+) = 1.50). which indicates a higher activity according to the Hutchings’ theory [4]. 4 Conclusions Here, we designed an excellent alternative catalyst for C2H2 activation. It back-donated more electrons to change the structure of C2H2, which activated it more rigorously than AuCl3-based catalysts. Further analysis revealed that the energies of FMOs, as well as their compositions calculated via NBO technique, interpret the structural and electron transformations during C2H2 coordination. Moreover, the pathways of HCl addition to Cl3Au(η2-C2H2) or IAu(η2-C2H2) were also illuminated based on NBO results, which implied a faster route on IAu(η2-C2H2). The calculations suggested the high stability of AuI. The experiments showed that 0.1Au(I)/AC2 exhibited extraordinarily high TOF and stability toward C2H2 treatment. The XRD patterns of AC1, 1Au(Cl3)/AC1 and 1Au(I)/AC1 treated by HCl for 30 min show that the iodide atomically stabilizes dispersed Au to protect Au+ from being reduced. It showed the ultra-high stability during the long-term, harsh testing, with comparable overall performance with commercial mercury catalyst. Thus, it is expected that 0.1Au(I)/AC2 is the most promising gold catalyst for industrial production of VCM to reach a TOF of 4582 h−1 since 1985. This work putted forward the efficiency of DFT and NBO in ligand design of gold center for adjusting the activity and stability of catalyst. References [1] B. Nkosi N.J. Coville G.J. Hutchings J. coredata.dc:description: Production of vinyl chloride monomer (VCM) via acetylene hydrochlorination reaction (AHR) is consuming huge amount of mercury catalyst that is highly toxic. A cheap, nontoxic, and effective alternate is urgently required. Here, we designed an AuI catalyst for AHR with the excellent catalytic performance. The designed 0.1AuI(wt%)/AC2 catalyst shows the comparable catalytic efficiency to the commercial mercury catalyst, which is applicable for industrial production of VCM. Theoretical calculations determine the activation mechanism of C2H2 by AuI, and highlight the high stability of AuI.
coredata.dc:title: AuI as a cheap, nontoxic, and efficient alternate to commercial mercury catalyst for production of vinyl chloride monomer
